preface.title: Welcome!

blockquote.title: Mission
blockquote.para: The DocCookBook project aims to create a collection of cookbook-style solutions released under a Creative Commons (CC) license for the international DocBook community.

preface.para: According to its homepage, DocBook is a schema (available in several languages including RELAX NG, SGML and XML DTDs, and W3C XML Schema) maintained by the DocBook Technical Committee of OASIS. It is particularly well suited to books and papers about computer hardware and software (though it is by no means limited to these applications).

Although there are helpful and valuable documentation like the DocBook 5: The Definitive Guide from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton 's DocBook XSL book, until now nobody wrote a book that combines the best of both worlds in a cookbook style. My book is intented to be such a book. However, it does not seek to replace the prior mentioned de facto standards. It aims for enhancing the world of DocBook with a different view.

My book is a collection of topics, specific to a certain problem.
Most topics contain step-by-step instructions to simplify your tasks for DocBook. If you want to dive deeper, I have collected links for further reading.

The topics are mostly based on my own experiences with DocBook and the DocBook XSL stylesheets. However, it also includes questions and answers from other sources: mostly the DocBook mailinglists, but also other sites that I have found. It is the nature of such topics that there might be some overlap with other sources. When other authors inspired me, I have included their names. If you think your name is missing, please let me know.

As I have learned a lot from the masters of DocBook, it is time to give something back. This book is written and available under a Creative Commons license. I hope the DocBook community will find it useful.

section.title: Audience
section.para: This book does not attempt to teach you DocBook or any other related technology (with the exception of ). It is targetted more for DocBook developers who seek concise examples for their problems. However, with some try-and-error it can also be useful for ordenary writers who wants to customize their documents. For readers who want further information are some links included in the See Also section at the end of each topic.

section.title: Further Readings
section.para: By no means is this book complete. As this book is based on technologies like CSS, XML, (X)HTML, and XSLT, it is always a good idea to seek other information. I highly recommend to read the books from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton as mentioned above.
